children.value: The process of defining company values

Gatsby is a distributed team, which means that on most days we only interact with contributors and team members through Slack and GitHub messages. And with team members everywhere from San Francisco to Chiang Mai, getting the whole team on extended video calls to discuss philosophical questions is extremely difficult.

led the effort by creating a Google Form to collect anonymous feedback on what Gatsby‚Äôs mission and values should be. We sent this form around to everyone and allowed a couple weeks for everyone to get their ideas in.

As we wrote these out, we discussed them with the whole team to make sure we weren‚Äôt oversimplifying or losing the message behind anyone‚Äôs ideas.
At the end of the exercise, we‚Äôd extracted 8 shared core values, all of which the team is fully aligned on and deeply committed to.

properties.ariaLabel: what we learned  gatsbys core values permalink

children.value: What we learned ‚Äî Gatsby‚Äôs core values
With our themes identified, we needed to polish our notes up into clear company values. Here‚Äôs what we settled on.

properties.ariaLabel: do the right thing when no one is looking permalink

children.value: Do the right thing when no one is looking

Companies live or die by the trust they build. Gatsby is an open source product, and that means we need to earn and maintain trust from our internal team, our larger community of contributors (and the open source community at large), as well as from our clients and customers.
To earn that trust, we need to be deeply committed to always doing the right thing
for the sake of doing the right thing
Our integrity ‚Äî both professional and personal ‚Äî is the foundation for everything else.
Open source is at the core of Gatsby‚Äôs success, and one of the central tenets of open source is that things are done in the open and without smoke, mirrors, pomp, circumstance, cloaks, or daggers.

Gatsby‚Äôs competitive advantage is the strength of its community and ecosystem, and we‚Äôre convinced that the right path forward is to continue working in the open, sharing our plans, ideas, struggles, and successes as transparently as possible.
unless it‚Äôs a critical competitive advantage, we‚Äôll put it in public.

properties.ariaLabel: set and manage clear expectations permalink

children.value: Setting and meeting expectations is the backbone of successful business (and people). It‚Äôs how we show respect, act professionally, and maintain healthy relationships.
If we say we‚Äôre going to do something, we‚Äôll do it.
If we‚Äôre going to miss a deadline, we‚Äôll tell you
it passes. We‚Äôll show up to meetings on time ‚Äî and if we‚Äôre going to be late, we‚Äôll email or text to let you know.

Behind all bad feelings ‚Äî anger, disappointment, frustration, and beyond ‚Äî there‚Äôs almost always a violated expectation. Gatsby is all about creating great experiences and good feelings, and managing expectations is how we make sure we live up to our goals.

properties.ariaLabel: go slow to go fast permalink

children.value: All projects are planned. The question is whether they‚Äôre planned upfront, or halfway through.

We understand the value of moving quickly and shipping things regularly. We also understand the value in first thinking things through to make sure we‚Äôre moving in the right direction and shipping the right things.
By taking the time up front to think through our goals and plan appropriately, we will avoid costly mistakes and slowdowns, keep the team and community on the same page, and ultimately move
than if we were charging ahead without thinking things through.

properties.ariaLabel: always prioritize developer experience and user experience permalink

children.value: Always prioritize developer experience and user experience

Whenever we make decisions, we will put the experience of the developers using Gatsby and the people who will use the sites generated by Gatsby first. Even if it means extra work to add helpful error messages. Even if it means refactoring a confusing API to be more user friendly.
Gatsby has built its reputation on being a pleasure to work with, and we‚Äôre dedicated to keeping that true.
Healthy things grow, and growing things change.
Gatsby is a fast-growing, cutting edge technology startup, and that means things are in near-constant flux. This means that we‚Äôre regularly up against circumstances that are rapidly evolving.

In order to survive and grow, we need to embrace growth as a healthy, vital process. This means making pragmatic decisions early, delegating when necessary, asking for help when it‚Äôs time, and recognizing how we‚Äôve always done things isn‚Äôt necessarily what works
. (And what works today may very well stop working tomorrow.)
These changes aren‚Äôt a sign that we‚Äôre failing, or that things are wrong. It‚Äôs a sign that the company is thriving.
Gatsby began as an experiment with bleeding edge technology. As a product, Gatsby has always aimed to be at the forefront of technological advances.
While we need to stick to our roadmap and make steady progress toward our company goals,
we will maintain a state of excitement about new technology and foster a culture of experimentation, play, and wonder.
We‚Äôre excited about reaching our goals and love to tinker. People are constantly creating incredible things, and it‚Äôs critical both to our success as a company
to our happiness as geeks that we take time to play with these incredible new technologies.
Open source doesn‚Äôt have the best reputation for being friendly and welcoming, and that makes us sad.
Everyone belongs in open source, and Gatsby is dedicated to making you feel welcome.
We will never judge, condescend, or exclude anyone. Instead, we will go above and beyond to support the community, through
, giving control to the community by
auto-inviting all contributors to the Gatsby GitHub org
, and other means that empower and embrace the incredible community that makes Gatsby possible.

properties.ariaLabel: how our company values will affect us going forward permalink

children.value: How our company values will affect us going forward
As a stand-alone list, these values are a great list of aspirational ideas, but they won‚Äôt mean much if we don‚Äôt put them into practice.

To ensure we live and work according to these values, we‚Äôre using our values as a key factor in our decision making process. As we put together our roadmap, define our internal workflow processes, or even plan a tweet or GitHub response, we‚Äôll be asking if the thing we‚Äôre about to do is lined up with our values.
